message_1: A survey of 500 college students found that 70% of them regularly exercise. Estimate the true proportion of all college students who regularly exercise using a confidence level of 95%.
message_2:
To estimate the true proportion of all college students who regularly exercise with a 95% confidence level, we will use the formula for the confidence interval of a proportion:

Confidence Interval = p-hat ± Z * sqrt((p-hat * (1 - p-hat)) / n)

where p-hat is the sample proportion, Z is the Z-score corresponding to the desired confidence level, and n is the sample size.

In this case, p-hat = 0.70 (70% of the 500 college students regularly exercise), n = 500, and the Z-score for a 95% confidence level is approximately 1.96.

Now, we can plug these values into the formula:

Confidence Interval = 0.70 ± 1.96 * sqrt((0.70 * (1 - 0.70)) / 500)

Confidence Interval = 0.70 ± 1.96 * sqrt((0.70 * 0.30) / 500)

Confidence Interval = 0.70 ± 1.96 * sqrt(0.21 / 500)

Confidence Interval = 0.70 ± 1.96 * sqrt(0.00042)

Confidence Interval = 0.70 ± 1.96 * 0.02049

Confidence Interval = 0.70 ± 0.04016

Confidence Interval = (0.65984, 0.74016)

Therefore, we can estimate with 95% confidence that the true proportion of all college students who regularly exercise is between 65.98% and 74.02%.
